0.text: My name is Katherine Barnett, I'm the housing collections manager at Chartwell,

6.text: So the original Jock, which was a gift given to Winston Churchill, for his 88th birthday,

11.text: was a marmalade cat, given by one of his private secretaries.

15.text: And Winston fell absolutely in love with this cat,

18.text: it was a really close companion for him, in the last few years of his life.

22.text: It was part of the request, to the National Trust, that we forever have a marmalade cat,

26.text: here in situ, to look exactly like the original Jock.

30.text: So Jock VI, who was known as Mally beforehand, had a very tough start unfortunately.

36.text: He was found a couple months ago, by a rescue charity, called Croydon Animal Samaritans.

41.text: He was in a bit of a poor state, he had some paint matted in his fur,

45.text: so we think he might've been sheltering from the storms we had,

48.text: earlier in the year, in someone's garage perhaps.

50.text: And, because of the timing, it's quite likely he was an unwanted Christmas gift, as well.

54.text: We think he is about seven months old, so still a kitten, but rather a large one, if I do say so myself.

60.text: His duties at Chartwell are mainly to welcome our visitors.

65.text: We have so many people coming here each year,

67.text: who want to see Jock, so really it's a very visitor facing role.

71.text: He's lovely, he's a really, really, caring, affectionate cat, as you can see,

75.text: he's really, really, good with people, but he does have a cheeky side as well.

79.text: If there's ever a cupboard he's not meant to go in,

80.text: I can guarantee you'll find him in there.
